chapter.title: Host Clusters
chapter.para: The cluster specific elements which may be contained in the cluster description are as follows:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: A server CPU reference which defines which CPU type must be supported by all hosts in the cluster. See
A reference to the data center of which this cluster is a member. See
The compatibility level of the cluster (see )
A list of the versions to which the cluster may be updated (see )
Defines the cluster's policy on host memory utilization. See below.
Defines the load-balancing or power sharing modes for hosts in the cluster. See below.
Defines virtual machine handling when a host within a cluster becomes non-operational. Requires an on_error element to define the property as migrate, do_not_migrate or migrate_highly_available

chapter.para: The memory_policy element can contain the following specific elements:

row.entry: The percentage of host memory allowed in use before no more virtual machines can start on a host. Virtual machines can use more than the available host memory due to memory sharing under KSM. Recommended values include 100 (None), 150 (Server Load) and 200 (Desktop Load).

chapter.para: The scheduling_policy element can contain the following specific elements:

row.entry: The VM scheduling mode for hosts in the cluster.

Defines CPU limits for the host. The high attribute controls the highest CPU usage percentage the host can have before being considered overloaded. The low attribute controls the lowest CPU usage percentage the host can have before being considered underutilized. The duration attribute refers to the number of seconds the host needs to be overloaded before the scheduler kicks in and moves the load to another host.

chapter.para: When creating a new cluster, the name, cpu id and datacenter properties are required. The datacenter may be identified by either name or id. Only the name, description and cpu id elements may be updated post-creation.

section.title: Associating Networks With a Cluster
section.para: The collection referenced by link rel="networks" represents the set of networks associated with a given cluster. Every host within the cluster must have a network interface attached to that network in order for the network to be operational.
The network representations are as described in , except they also contain a cluster id reference to the cluster in question.

The networks collection may be manipulated as described in . Associating a network with the cluster is achieved by POSTing a network reference (identifying the network either by its id or name) to the collection. Removing an association is achieved by DELETEing the appropriate element in the collection.
